description: The round payoff this round was 2. You, John chose to play option 2.Kate chose to play option 2. You received a payoff of -2000.

The payoff structure creates a high-stakes tension between safe and aggressive moves. Choosing option1 is the safe default since mutual option1 yields a neutral (0) result, whereas opting for option2 is risky—it offers a gain when the opponent sticks to option1 but leads to a huge penalty (the input multiplied by 1000 in the negative) if both choose option

The memory from 2024‑01‑02 illustrates the concrete risk: you chose option2 and so did Kate, resulting in a massive negative payoff (–2000) when the round input was 2. This shows that even if a player is tempted by the prospect of gaining the round input, mutual aggressive play is dangerous and demonstrates how easily the punishment mechanism can be triggered.

Overall, the game incentivizes sticking to the default (option1) to avoid the catastrophic outcome of mutual aggression, but it also embeds a temptation: if you can predict that the other player will remain default, choosing option2 potentially gives you a small reward. This creates a strategic dilemma between short-term gains and the long-term risk of iterative punishment.
